article.description: Romain Sato scored 15 of his 23 points in the first half Saturday night as Xavier (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) built a big early lead and coasted to an 84-60 victory over Eastern Kentucky.
article.headline: West rips into Musketeers after routing E. Kentucky
article.linkText: Xavier rolls, but West agonizes over 'lack of cohesiveness'
article.story:
CINCINNATI (AP) -- David West expected big things when he stayed
at Xavier for his senior season. He doesn't like how it's turning out.

Romain Sato scored 15 of his 23 points in the first half Saturday night as Xavier (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) built a big early lead and coasted to an 84-60 victory over Eastern Kentucky.

After the lopsided win, West tore into his team, saying Xavier (8-2) won't come close to meeting expectations until it develops more cohesiveness.

"I don't know how Coach is going to take this, but we're not playing together like a team,'' said West, who had 13 points and 13 rebounds despite an eye injury. "That's obvious. The village idiot can see that.

"We've got guys on the team who won't pass to other guys, who don't rebound or don't screen if they don't get their touches. We're just not playing together.''

Coach Thad Matta concurred.

"He said what I said,'' Matta said. "In the game of basketball, I have yet to see a championship team that has one guy win it for them.''

Eastern Kentucky (5-5) was so determined to stop West that it packed in its zone defense, leaving open shots for Sato on the perimeter. Sato was 5-of-11 on 3-point attempts.

Sato emerged from a five-game shooting slump by scoring 33 points in a victory at Siena on Monday night, regaining his touch and his confidence. He shot without hesitation once again Saturday, hitting his first three attempts.

"I came out shooting,'' said Sato, who fixed some flaws. "Coach told me to keep on shooting.''

Shawn Fields scored 18 points and Kenyatta Dix had 15 for Eastern Kentucky. Freshman guard Matt Whitt, who leads the Colonels with a 14.2-point average, was only 3-of-16 from the field for six points.

Xavier's worst moments have come in its biggest games -- losses
to Stanford in the Preseason NIT and to Mississippi State. The
Musketeers get a chance to save face or lose respect in their next
two games, against No. 18 Creighton on Tuesday and at No. 1 Alabama
on Saturday.

West shudders at what will happen in the next week unless Xavier gets a lot better.

"We're setting ourselves up for a pretty bad whipping over the next couple of games,'' he said.

Xavier was never seriously challenged by Eastern Kentucky, which rushed shots against the Musketeers' switching man-to-man defense and quickly fell behind.

"We played one of our better games, but you're playing against one of the best teams in the country,'' coach Travis Ford said. "There's a reason we missed open shots: We were trying to get rid of it before they got back to us.''

The Colonels were just 3-of-19 from the field as Xavier pulled out to a 24-6 lead. On defense, Eastern Kentucky stayed in its zone and bracketed West with 7-foot center Tim Volpenhein and another player whenever he got the ball.

West was content to pass to his unguarded shooters. Xavier shot 57 percent in the first.

West got poked in the left eye as he drove inside and was fouled
with 3:08 left in the half. He repeatedly blinked to try to clear
his vision, made two free throws, then took himself out of the
game. Trainers flushed his eye for the rest of the half.

"I couldn't see,'' West said. "It kind of blurred my vision for a while.''

Sato made a pair of free throws and a 3-pointer as Xavier pushed
the lead to 28 points early in the second half, then relaxed.

Eastern Kentucky got it down to 16 midway through the half, but West made a pull-up jumper and passed inside to Anthony Myles for a layup that started a seven-point spurt and finished off the Colonels.
